passages.text: Fundamentals struggling for now, but should improve once raw milk cost picks up (likely mid- 26); attractive valuation

Mengniu's 1H25 reported earnings were down \(16.4\%\) yoy (a miss) on a sales decline of \(6.9\%\) yoy (broadly in- line). Stripping out: 1) China Modern Dairy loss and 2) gain on subsidiary disposal, adjusted earnings were up \(12.2\%\) yoy (broadly in- line). Raw milk cost declined \(2.5\%\) from Jan to Jun, and 1H25 average cost was down \(12\%\) yoy. This resulted in an \(11\%\) sales decline for liquid milk (accounting for \(77\%\) group sales), and offset the positive impact from successful opex savings. Mengniu's share price is down \(10\%\) YTD (vs Yili's down \(8\%\) , HSI up \(25\%\) and CSI 300 index up \(13\%\) ). Trading at 11.7x 2025 P/E (vs Yili's 16x, all on Bloomberg consensus earnings estimates), we think the uncertainty of raw milk cost (the major drag/driver for fundamentals) has been largely discounted in the share price. Once raw milk cost picks up (likely in 2026 summer, vs our previous expectation of 2025 summer), Mengniu's fundamentals should gradually recover and a valuation re- rating would follow, in our view. We remain OW on Mengniu for the potential fundamental turnaround with a new Dec- 26 PT of HK\$22 (vs Jun- 26 HK\$24).

- What's good? 1) OpCF increased \(46\%\) yoy, well outpacing operating profit up \(13.4\%\) yoy. 2) Fresh milk sales were up \(20\% +\) (well outperforming industry growth), ice cream sales up \(15\%\) , cheese up \(12\%\) and IMF up \(2.5\%\) . 3) Gross margin expanded 1.5ppt to \(41.7\%\) on easing input costs. 4) Selling expense was down \(8.4\%\) yoy, leading to stable SG&A/sales ratio. 5) OP margin expanded 1.5ppt to \(8.5\%\) . 6) Capex was cut by \(40\%\) yoy to Rmb1bn. 7) Net debt declined to Rmb14bn from Rmb17.3bn (end-2024). 8) Committed to shareholder returns (dividend payout to rise from 2024 level of \(43\%\) ; to continue share buybacks).

- What's not good? 1) Liquid milk sales declined \(11\%\) yoy on a \(6 - 7\%\) sales volume decline and a \(4 - 5\%\) ASP drop. Raw milk cost declined \(2.5\%\) from Jan to Jun to Rmb3.04/kg; 1H25 average cost was down \(12\%\) yoy. Small brands have been gaining share through irrational discounts. Mengniu started cutting plain milk price in Jun 2025, implying margin pressure in 2H25. 2) China Modern Dairy reported a loss of Rmb914mn, resulting in an associate contribution to Mengniu of negative Rmb544mn (vs Rmb133mn loss in 1H24). This led to a 1H25 reported earnings miss, in addition to zero subsidiary disposal gain in 1H25 (vs Rmb269mn in 1H24).

- 2H25 outlook and guidance. 1) Mengniu noted that current end-demand (especially for 3Q25 a traditional high season) remains lukewarm and expects full-year 2025 sales to decline mid- to high-single digit (implying 2H25 sales growth would be similar to 1H25's -6.9%). 2) The company expects raw milk cost in 2H25 would remain at similar level as 1H25, which implies 2H25 average cost to decline 4% yoy. As of late-Aug, market raw milk price was Rmb3.02/kg (-3% YTD, -6% yoy). 3) Mengniu expects 2025 full-year OP margin to be flattish vs 2024, implying 2H25 OP margin to erode 1.6ppt yoy to 7.8% (vs 1.5ppt expansion to 8.5% in 1H25).
Price Target (Dec- 26): HK\$22.00 Prior (Jun- 26): HK\$24.00

We are OW on Mengniu. Though fundamentals will likely remain weak in 2H25, we think the uncertainty of raw milk cost (the major drag/driver for fundamentals) has been largely discounted in the share price. Once raw milk cost picks up (likely in 2026 summer, vs our previous expectation of 2025 summer), Mengniu's fundamentals would gradually recover and a valuation re- rating would follow, in our view. With better free cash flow (1H25 OpCF up \(46\%\) yoy and capex down \(40\%\) yoy), Mengniu could increase DPS yoy (we estimate a \(50\%\) payout on 2025 reported earnings). We forecast sales to decline \(6.6\%\) yoy and adjusted earnings to grow \(3.2\%\) yoy in 2025. We forecast sales/adj earnings to grow \(3.5\% /12.5\%\) CAGR over 2025- 27.

Our DCF- based Dec- 26 PT of HK\$22.0 implies 14.6x/13.2x 2026/27 P/E. We derive our \(9.8\%\) WACC for Mengniu assuming a \(3.1\%\) risk- free rate, a \(7\%\) risk premium, and \(20\%\) optimal leverage. We assume a terminal growth rate of \(1\%\) .
Figure 1: China raw milk price and yoy growth from 2009 to date
Source: Ministry of Agriculture of China (as of 28 August 2025).

We cut our 2025- 27 earnings estimates by \(10 - 13\%\) , mainly due to: 1) a \(9\%\) cut in sales forecast (a slower- than- expected demand recovery in 2025) and 2) higher loss from associate contributions in 2025 (i.e. China Modern Dairy).

Post the earnings revisions, we forecast sales to decline \(6.6\%\) yoy and adjusted earnings to grow \(3.2\%\) yoy in 2025. We forecast sales/adj earnings to record \(3.5\% /12.5\%\) CAGR over 2025- 27E.
Table 1: Summary of earnings revisions and key assumption changes
Source: Mengine report (2024), J.P. Morgan estimates.
Table 2: Summary of P&L – Mengniu
Source: Mengniu reports (2021-1H25), J.P. Morgan estimates. Note: (*) positive value for expenses incurred in reported net profit and negative value for gains included in reported net profit.

PT revision- We roll over our price target date from Jun 2026 to Dec 2026.- We cut our DCF- based PT to HK\$22 (from HK\$24), mainly due to the earnings downgrade, partly offset by the effect of the PT horizon rollover.- We maintain our WACC assumptions in the DCF model.- Our DCF- based PT implies \(14.6x / 13.2x\) 2026/27 P/E, comparable to Yili's \(14.5x / 13.3x\) on consensus estimates.
